lines.text: Love has got to stop some place short of suicide.
[last lines]
Are you going back to that washed-out expatriate in Naples?
Yes, and when I marry her, I'm going back to doing things.
Do you think you'll ever get me out of your blood?
Maybe not, but love has got to stop someplace short of suicide.
[Dodsworth runs to the gangplank and jumps on just as it is lowered away from the ship. The boat whistle sounds]
But the gentleman will miss the boat!

[shouting above the boat whistle]
HE'S GONE ASHORE! HE'S GONE ASHORE!
Remember, I, I did make a home for you once, and I'll do it again, only you've got to let me have my fling now! Because you're simply rushing at old age, Sam, and I'm not ready for that yet.
You'll have to stop getting younger someday.
I hope I look as good as you do when I'm your age.
You're almost sure to, my dear.
I suppose people travel to get away from themselves.

[to Fran]
Have you thought how little happiness there can be for the... *old* wife... of a young husband?
Oh, you're hopeless - you haven't the mistiest notion of civilization.
Yeah, well maybe I don't think so much of it, though. Maybe clean hospitals, concrete highways, and no soldiers along the Canadian border come near my idea of civilization.
Would you like to enjoy life for a while?
Show me how.
You want to divorce me then?
Why should I want to divorce you? You're my husband.
You couldn't very well divorce me if I weren't.
[first lines]

[offscreen]
Mr. Dodsworth?
Yes.
The men are ready.
I want to sit under a Linden tree with nothing more important to worry about but the temperature of the beer. If there is anything more important.

[walking into the scene of a platonic goodbye kiss]
Would you lay off those European liberties with my wife?
We'll have to learn to behave ourselves, when we'll be a couple of old grandparents in December.
